titleStmt.title: Prophet Ayyub Harran

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.
Private URIs using the dict prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a entry in the SHAWI glossary.

spanGrp.span: It is said in the stories and according to what is mentioned that the Prophet Job (Ayyub) is believed to have his shrine here.
His shrine is here, meaning the place where he endured his suffering, but the actual tomb is located elsewhere, outside the city.
It is said that Prophet Job (Ayoub) was very rich in the past. He had a lot of wealth, livestock, and many sons and daughters.
It is said that he worshipped his Lord diligently, and then Satan came to the Lord of the Worlds and asked: "Why does he worship You?"
"He worships You because You have given him his wealth and possessions, so surely he will worship You!"
"Take away his wealth and see, take away his children and see if he will still worship You!"
It is said that Allah tested him with his wealth and children, placing him in a trial that lasted for 13 or 18 years.
It is said that one day, a great earthquake struck his house, causing the death of his sons and daughters.
It is said that when he came to deliver the news of the tragedy, the devil appeared to him in a different form, trying to mislead him and shake his faith.
He comes to him and says: "O Prophet Job! There was an earthquake, and your children were still inside the house, and they died."
He says, "These were given by God," meaning his heart is brave. The other person tries to console him, but he says, "These were given by God, and He is the one who took them."
Meaning, he is not affected and says, "Praise be to God." When the Lord of the worlds gives, He is the one who gave, and He is the one who took.
He says: "He still worships You!" The devil says: "Of course, he will worship You, of course, he will worship You."
Now, look, he had wealth and property. His children are gone, but he still has his wealth, so that’s why he worships You.
It is said that a flood occurred, sweeping away all of his wheat and his entire land.
It is said that a flood occurred, taking away all his wealth and livestock. Nothing remained with him.
The devil comes again and says: "O Prophet Job! Did you not know? Your wealth and livestock are gone. The flood has taken them." He replies: "Praise be to Allah."
This wealth (provision) belongs to the Lord of the worlds. He gave it, and He took it. So, he continued to worship his Lord once again.
Meaning, despite what happened to him, he continued to worship and turn back to the Lord of the worlds. As for Satan, may Allah's curse be upon him.
He said: "Look! You said in the beginning that Prophet Job had wealth and possessions. You took his children, his wealth, and his possessions, but he still worships Me."
He said: "Of course he will worship You! Because his body is still healthy." So, Allah decreed afflictions upon him.
Due to the severity of the illness, the people of the village where he lived no longer accepted or wanted him. No one would approach him because of his sickness.
They saw how his flesh would fall off and be left on the ground.
Ah! And Prophet Ayub came to this cave here and entered it.
No one would approach him except his wife, as she was compassionate and would come to him.
No one would approach him, and despite the fact that all his wealth, belongings, and everything else had gone, he still kept saying, "Praise be to Allah."
He worshiped his Lord while in his state of illness and kept saying, "Praise be to Allah."
To the point that they reached a stage where they could no longer find a loaf of bread. His wife went to the bakery, seeking some bread.
He said to her, "Give me one of your braids so I can give you some bread." She had braids.
She cut off one of her braids and gave it to the baker, receiving bread in return.
When she brought him the bread, he looked at it and saw that her braid was no longer there.
He asked, "Where is your braid?" She didn't answer. He repeated, "Your braid?" She replied, "I gave it to the baker."
He said, "Go and take back your bread and retrieve your braid. We don’t need the bread."
She went, returned the bread, and got her braid back.
And they remained in this state until it reached a point where he was screaming. Even the devil said: "Alright, he truly worships his Lord!"
Then God granted him wealth again and told him: "You have that well beside you" which we have seen. He said to Prophet Job.
According to the narrations, the well next to him erupted.
He said: "O Prophet Ayoub, wash yourself." This was all revealed through inspiration, where a voice came saying: "Wash with this water and drink, and you will see healing."
He got up, washed with the water from the well, drank from it, and was healed.
It is said that when he was ill, worms began to eat away at his body.
Every human has worms. The dead person has worms inside them. The worms come from the earth. Our flesh is the flesh of human beings, and it becomes infested with worms.
Now, the meat that is placed under the sun becomes infested with worms.
It is said that when a worm would fall, he would pick it up from the ground, place it on his foot, and say: "Eat! Eat your provision! Eat your provision, O worm!"
He endured and was patient to such an extent, suffering for 18 years through trials. After Allah confirmed that his worship was sincere...
The water emerged from the earth for him, and he bathed in it and drank from it, restoring his health.
Then Allah returned his wealth and blessings, and he was given children once again—daughters, meaning he returned to his previous, comfortable state.
This is the story of Prophet Job.
